Yours Truly

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires

( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name ........................................... Wilfred Stanley Fawell

2. Your address ............................................. Box 89, Girvin, Sask.

3. Date ......................................................... Jan. 4th, 1955.

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   May 2nd, 1888, In Township of Oneida, County of Haldimand Prov., Ontario.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   John Fawell, Farmer, P.O. DeCewsville Ont.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year).
   In July 1905. (Three days before Saskatchewan was made a Province.)

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan,
   giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need
   to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a
   small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   I came with my father and was 17 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?
    Railroad or government information?)

The Thompsons mentioned in the party afore, were sons of S.J. Thomson who came west
in the early eighties. They settled and farmed two sections immediately west of Carberry
Manitoba. Their father had sold their holdings and they were going west to start on their
own. They joined the eastern party at Winnipeg and went west in 1904. May have had corre-
spondence that I know nothing about.

3. Date ................................................................. Jan. 8th, 1955

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ......................................................... May 2nd, 1908, In Township of Osada, County of Haliburton, Prov. Ontario.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? ................................................................. John Fawell, Farmer, P. O., Okotoks, Alta.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year) .................................................. In July 1905. (Three days before Saskatchewan was made a Province.)

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?) ......................... The Fawells went west. They settled in the party after the party left. They were told by their friends that they were going west. They had heard stories from their friends that they were going west. They knew nothing about it.
Father and his two brothers sold their Ontario farms in the winter of 1904. He moved his family, wife and two children to Caledonia, fourteen miles south of Hamilton while he came west to homestead. A man by the name of Carpenter had located and filed on homesteads for them near Lloydminster by proxy. There were a party of nine or ten. The Barr Colonists were settling there that same spring. They unloaded their horses and equipment at Saskatoon and drove to Battleford and on west to Lloydminster. Not satisfied with the location and land returned to Battleford.

Here they filed on homesteads thirty-eight miles south-west in the Swarthmore area. In the party were my father, John Fawell, two brothers Will and Edd and son Leslie and his brother-in-law, Will Lack. There were three Thompson brothers, Chester Clarence and Earl, nephews of my father and Geo. Foster Brother-in-law of Will Fawell. Father was the cook for the party. Father became so crippled with rheumatism he had to return back east. His brother and Geo Foster returned with him. On returning home he met a Dr. Rolston who lived in Cuba. He persuaded father that the warm climate would be good for his rheumatism and to come back with him. His brother and he went to Cuba and stayed the winter. They each bought ten acre farms and worked at carpenter work while there. His rheumatism left him completely and not liking the natives again returned to Ontario in May of 1905. I could see no future in clerking at three dollars a week and wanted to come west my cousins by this time had came out. So we left the second time for the west and settled here.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other exact moments, etc.)

There was nothing eventful only the two day train ride to which we had never been.

I was two months in Winnipeg before coming to Alberta. I boarded a few days with a family by the name of Hamilton who later located at Parsonage Street. We bought a two room house and moved in during the spring with them. While we were there my first work in Saskatchewan. They hired a hundred acres broke by the steam enginering pulling a huge plough owned by Mr. Hallett who was located in this district. This was my first experience at driving oxen. Their limit was twelve miles a day. That is a job to teach you how to operate and never get in a hurry.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I left Winnipeg the last week of August Saskatchewan, then known as Assiniboina N.W.T.

It was opened exhibition week in August 1909. It only covered half a block and five stores high.

To the farm we bought and I started my first work in Saskatchewan. They hired a hundred acres broke by the steam enginering pulling a huge plough owned by Mr. Hallett who was located in this district. This was my first experience at driving oxen. Their limit was twelve miles a day. That is a job to teach you how to operate and never get in a hurry.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

We settled on a farm three and a half mile norther east of Gravenhurst. (Sec. 33, Tp. 22 Rg. 28 W. 2nd M.)

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We have resided the last five years in Gravenhurst. My son Hosea S. recently is now residing and working. In 1909 I broke out on the virgin prairie from 1909 to 1909.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

My parents in Ontario came out and started to clerk in R.E. Walker's hardware store on my coming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They regretted us going so far away but soon came to visit and see our new home in the west. Many took advantage of the cheap harvesters' excursion tickets to make us a visit and aid with the harvest.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Father and I came west by ourselves.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We came on what was known as a homestead ticket.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

There was nothing eventful only the two day train ride to me who had never been away from home before. Father lost me with my aunt and uncle in Winnipeg till he located a place to settle. Uncle was director of light horse exhibit at Winnipeg exhibition being held for one week during my stay with them. Uncle got me a job as secretary for the Light Horse Judge and a pass to the grounds plus ten dollars a day. I was in John T. Eaton store the first day it was opened. It was opened exhibition week in August 1905. It only covered half a block and five stories high. I left Winnipeg the last week of August Saskatchewan. Then known as Assiniboina N.W.T.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I was two months in Winnipeg before coming to Givrin. I boarded a few days with a family by the name of Hamilton who later located at Wainwright Sask. We bought a two room house and moved by the steam engine pulling a nine furrow plough owned by A.B. Hasekton who was located in this district. This was my first experience at driving oxen. Their limit was twelve miles a day. That is a job to teach you to be patient and never try in a hurry.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

We settled on a farm three and a half miles north east of Givrin. (Sec. 25, TP. 25, Rg. 25, W. 2nd N.R.)

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We have resided the last five years in Givrin. My son Ross S. Fawell is now residing and working the I broke out on the virgin prairie from 1905 to 1908.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My parents in Caledonia Ont. and started to clerk in R.E. Walker's hardware store on my fourteenth birthday for the large salary of $20.00 a week. The hours were from six A.M. to 10 P.M. Six days a week with an hour for dinner. For there till Dec. 31, 1904. On Jan. 2nd, 1905 in a General Store for an advance of one dollar a week I worked till the first of June. On the sixth of June father and son left Caledonia for a little home in the golden west, landed in Winnipeg on the morning of June the 8th, 1905. I stayed with my aunt and uncle Mr. and Mrs. S.J. Thompson while father went west to locate.
11. What did you friends and relatives think of your decision to come to West?

They repeated so often so far away but soon came to visit and see our new home in the west.

Many took advantage of the cheap harvest extermination tickets to make us a visit and aid with the harvest.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Father and I came west by ourselves.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came on what was known as a horse seekers ticket.

14. What memories of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

There was nothing eventful only the two day train ride to me who had never been away from home before. Rather late at night horses exterminated being loaded for overnight duty the next day. We stayed there until the next day for the light force used a pass to the grounds plus ten dollars a day. I was in the Eaton store the first day it was opened. It was opened exactly one week in August 1905. It only covered half a block and five stories high.

I left Winnipeg the last week of August Saskatchewan, then known as Assiniboin N.W.T.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

The name of Hamilton was located at Steeles. We sought a two room house and worked for the owner who was located in the same town. They hired a hundred acres broke by the steam engine pulling a nine plough owned by A.R. Heaton who was located in the district. This was my first experience of living there. I felt very lonely and was eager for a job to teach you to be patient and never go in hurry.

16. Have did you settle or take up land?

We settled down a farm three and a half miles north east of Grivin. (Sec. 37, Tp. 25, Rg. 26, W. 2nd M.)

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We have resided the last five years in Grivin. My son Ross S. Farrell is now residing and working. I broke out on the original property from 1905 to 1909.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My parents in Scotland came, and started to clerk in P.E. Walker's Hardware store on May 1st. Every fourth Saturday for the large salary of $3.00 a week hours were from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M. Six days a week and one hour for meals. We were there till Oct. 15th, 1904. On Jan. 2nd, 1905 in a General Strike for an advance of one dollar a week where I worked till the first of June. On the sixth of June father and son left Edmonton for a little home in the golden west. Located in Thompson while further went west to Locates.
12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Father and I came west by ourselves.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came on what was known as a horse seekers ticket.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

There was nothing eventful only the two day train ride to me who had never been away from home before. Father left me with my aunt and uncle in Winnipeg till I was placed in a school during my stay with them. Uncle got me the job as settler helper at Winnipeg's exhibition being held to convince the world of the light horse exhibit for the light horse huge sale. It was opened on the grounds plus ten dollars a day. I was in the T. Eaton store the first day it was opened. I left Winnipeg the last week of August, 1905. In the T. Eaton store the first day it was opened.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I was two months in Winnipeg before coming to Glivin. I boarded a few days with a family by the name of Hamilton who later located at Vaterburn, Sask. We bought a two room house and moved into the farm we bought and started my first work in Saskatchewan. The farm was owned by Mr. Hamilton. They had a hundred acres broken by the steam engine pulling a nine furrow plough owned by Mr. Hamilton. This land was located in the district. This was my first experience at driving over. That fall it was twelve miles a day. That I worked hard.

16. Where did you settle or settle up land?

We settled on a farm three and a half miles north east of Girvin. (Sec. 57, TP. 25, Rg. 25, W. 2nd, M.)

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We have resided the last five years in Girvin, my new residence and working place. I broke out on the virgin prairie from 1905 to 1908.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

My parents in Caldonia Ont., and started to clerk in R.S. Walter's hardware store on the 14th of June. Father birthday for the large sale. We worked six days a week with an hour for meals. We worked until Jan. 31, 1904. On Jan. 2nd, 1905 in a General store for an advance of four dollars a week. I worked until June 1st. On the 1st of June, on the morning of June the 8th, 1905, I started with my aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. G.J. Thompson on the way to locate.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old house?

We wrote regularly to our folks in the east. In 1912 we went east for three months' visit.

The following year we had many relatives and friends come west to visit. Harvest time would be hard with work. I had a cousin go, parallel, so, Oattinger, Carter, in 1914 and worked for eight months five successive years.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

We married at Eleven on Dec. 1916 to Emma P. Hawkins who came west in 1912 from Belleville Ontario with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. Hawkins an older sister, and three brothers.

21. Did anyone else come to Sebastopol because of your recommendation? It was a place to settle?

I really could not say our coming was influenced any one else.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west

Tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

The winter of 1907-8 was the longest and the most snow we ever had in my memory. The morning of Nov. 14 1906 was a nice bright clear beginning for any day. By noon there was snow and became colder and by night were having one of the worst blizzards I ever saw this side, east or west. On and to the top of snow on the level. Blizzards all over wasting the pasture took everything but the grasses.

Foot of snow on the level. Blizzards all over wasting the pasture took everything to your knees in the snow. During the winter we were without water during the whole time it was a blizzard the first year and until we moved into Sebastopol three years after.

The food necessities were on short rations, such as flour, sugar, tea, coffee, coal, oil.

The following days dry food was scarce, sometimes none through and reflected the shortage of coal and groceries. The cattle clip up so high we had trouble with a few days meat left in the provision and refused starvation to pass on the road. A turn off generally meant an up set. Our first three weeks on the road a turn off generally meant an up set.

Our first mode of transportation was a wagon and a team of mules with freight from Dr. Tanner.

Our traveling was limited to going to church and that which was really necessary. If we went west by train. My first car travel of any length was from Sebastopol to Chicago in 1914. Our first motion trip was to visit relatives settled at Auburn in this same state.

Went by way of Sebastopol, Ligger and Wilco. The roads were just ruts and gravel and in some settle the year. We would acquire our way to the next town and so till we landed there.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

Visit
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

We wrote regularly to our folk in the east. In 1912 we went east for three months visit.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Was married at Glengarry, Dec. 13, 1916 to Emma P. Hawkins who came west in 1912 from Belleville, Ontario with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Wm. Hawkins an older brother, and three brothers.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, where did they settle?

I really could not say our coming was influential anyone else.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My sister came west with us and took a business course in Winnipeg at St. Mary's Academy. On completion of her course she took a position as stenographer in the Davidson branch of the Bank of British North America in 1966. In 1974 she went into training for a nurse at Winnipeg City Hospital. On completion of her graduation she was three years in surgery at Winnipeg General Hospital. She went to Hollywood Hospital, Los Angeles and is still living there.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

The winter of 1966-7 was the longest and the worst snow we ever had in my memory. The morning of Nov. 14, 1966 was a nor'easter blowing clear for any day. By noon began to snow and before dark and by night we had one of the worst blizzards I ever saw in the west. We had two feet of snow on the level. Drifts all over making the prairie look like a huge sea of white. In the top of drifts was hard enough to carry a horse and man through. One day without any train or car. It was on a Sunday. The snow during the winter was twenty-five inches deep. The first train and mail came through, and we received the first mail and newspapers on short notice. Such as: Postage stamps, newspapers, coal, matches, yeast and other goods. The following day travel was impossible due to high traffic rules. Go to town next on the post office. Our first snow was on Friday the 2nd. The snow was so heavy a stand the front came before they matured. Some wheat was saved from thirty pounds a bushel.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Our first mode of transportation was a wagon and a team of mules necessary if we went any distance. Our traveling was limited to going to church and that which was necessary. If we went any further than a mile it was by train. By train, car travel of any length was from Regina with our family to our district. In 1914, our first car travel was to visit relatives settled at Adanac in the eastern district. We went by way of Saskatoon, Biggar and Wilcox. The roads were just cut and we turned there. Settlers yard. We would unhitch our way to the next town and go on till we turned there.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

The first car, a Ford by L.S. Tomesend, Mr. of S.A. Peterson's 252nd Station Road, 4 miles from Alfriston.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

Bought a Ford, it was a model T Ford.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your house?

Our trading point was Old Town Hall, two and a half miles. Bearden and Oracle were both nine miles away and larger towns.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns)

Operating, better means of travel, etc.,

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

We had not day as a few minutes would take us in town.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town reg-

ularity on Sundays?

It was slaves a question to go to town on Saturday evenings.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to bury through the mail order catalogues?

What kind of articles did you bury in this way? Hint: these also went to town.

Of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

We have bought more or less through the catalogue. In the early days it was the only place for a variety of articles. Perhaps especially records of clothing was bought from the catalogue. We buy very little this way now. We have our own 50-50 store and buy anything you may ask for. It is one of the largest and easiest in the province. Our extended amount to a tidy sum every year that we can't afford to buy elsewhere.

32. When (if ever) did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

V. 32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

Answer above.

33. When you came to Seaford when the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

The same here intention of making this a permanent home.

Twenty-four hour continuous service.

The central office was in the Alfred Post Office. This company was known as the Alfred Rural Telephone Co. It was resulted with the central located in Bridgton and have
25. When was the first car used in the community?

The first car, a Ford by L.E. Townsend, Mgr., of S.S. (not known), Section Park, 4 miles from Glivin.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

Bought our first car in the spring of 1914 from J.P. Ross of Glivin.

Delivered it. It was a model T Ford.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

Our trading point was Glivin. Both David and Orals were both within miles away from larger towns.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new teams appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

We have always got our mail and traded here. All grain is delivered in Glivin.

I deliver all my grain and traded here. All grain is delivered in Glivin.

We have always got our mail and traded here. All grain is delivered in Glivin.

Board of directors for years will be remembered with the Davidson Co-op. In 1949, J.A. Andrew who was president at that time is still a member on the Davidson Co-op Board.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

We had no set day as a few minutes would take us in town.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

It was always a question to go to town on Saturday evenings.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of purchases were made by mail order and any changes in the proportion.

32. Our first telephone company was organized in 1908 and built the following year. The first line and repair work was done by Mr. Switzer. The company was known as the Rural Telephone Co. It was built six years ago with the central located in Davidson and has twenty-four hour continual service.

33. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

Answer above.

34. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

We came here intention of making this a permanent home.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1917? What reasons

There were some residents and people on small farms who went north and have never returned.

I have no knowledge of any returning.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

There were some residents and people on small farms who went north and have never returned.

I have no knowledge of any returning.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My wife's parents (Mr. and Mrs. Mr. Hartman) and mine were both old Methodist Church members back in Ontario and still connected until my 1925 or 24. The present church was built by the united congregations in 1925.

The first lodge in Ontario was the Modern Woodmen of America. A number of members from the Steuben had started in the district, By chance in Regina I met two Canadian organizers and he organized a Lodge. He had a large membership for the district and used also at a time till the Lodge went dormant.

At one time the members gathered over fifty thousand dollars in insurance with the M.W.A. lodge.

I was Sec.-Treas., from start to finish.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "pioneer" to have or do some-

thing in the district mention it here stating dates wherever possible.

(Just as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge,

etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts,

Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to

give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin

and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names

since the first name was given and reason for change. Give dates of

new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

39. Willit Turner, a veterinary from Mount Forest, Ontario came west around the turn of the

century and settled at Eagle Rock and followed his profession among the resources in that

district for a time. He retired in 1940 with his wife and daughter. He lived

in town and practiced his profession and sold farm remedies. He also had a milk collection farm.

He bought our farm from the Postville Land and Grading Company of Iowa, through him.

Mrs. Turner told me the town was named after her twin sisters' husband whose name was Giverton.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1917? What reasons did they have for moving?

There were a number about this time (1917) who went west to Alaska, Montana, Idaho, Oregon, and California. Many were starting for their new homes.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

There were a few returns and people on small farms who went north and have never returned.

I have no knowledge of any returning.

By wife's parents (Mr. and Mrs. W. Hawkins), who were both old Methodist Church members back in Ontario and still continued until 1911 when they moved to Ontario. In 1925 I joined the United Church of Canada.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, Villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.)

Give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the above in (1), (2), (3).

Dr. Willet Temner, a missionary from Mount Pleasant, Ontario came west around the turn of the century and settled at Rayla Creek and followed his profession among the ranchers in the district for a time. I believe he came to Girvin in 1904 with his wife and daughter. He lived in town and practiced his profession on and off until 1911. We bought our farm from the Porterville Land and Gold mining Company of Iowa through him.

Mrs. Temner told me the town was named after her twin sisters' husbands who were from Girvin.
